title: Hi! I'm Zaps - ask me anything!
body:
Hey there!

**I'm Zaps - and I work as a Live Service Data Analyst at Riot Oceania.** Basically I analyse data about player connectivity or technical issues - as well as creating tools that help Riot Oceania identify and resolve player pain.

I've been working at Riot since mid 2013. I previously worked in the NOC, as well as working as a Live Tech for a while. 

I'm a sucker for fantasy, science fiction and pretty much reading in general. When it comes to gaming, I'm a sucker for pretty much any kind of RPG - especially ARPGs and JRPGs! My first gaming console was a Super Nintendo, and I still think it's one of (maybe the!) best consoles of all time!

I'm also a bit of a cricket tragic - love the game, love watching it... but horrible at playing it. For context of how bad - one of my greatest achievements was managing to get 2 runs in 20 overs coming in at #11! It didn't even save the game!

**Please, ask me anything! I promise that I won't bite that much!**

_EDIT: I've had to slow down a bit for the night, so I'm sorry if I haven't replied to you yet! I'll still be answering questions over time! Feel free to ask more questions if you have them!_

_This is a little outside my area but I'll just go into some non-specific parts of why something like this is problematic! _

In general, there's an issue with this idea around the way that a client-server model works.

If it was possible to detect when a client was disconnected as opposed to intentionally leaving the game - then players who wanted to intentional leave could just intentionally force themselves to be disconnected.  

In this particular case, information about the connection is coming from the client - which can be easily falsified (unplug your PCs network cable, set up a firewall to block your connection to the server, etc.) and therefore can't be trusted for a system like this.

Maybe you can try looking for a pattern between time, ping and disconnection with statistics as unplugging the router is more sudden than getting 900 ping then disconnecting a minute after. It's also a lot harder to fake ping as you'd have to guess around and run several bandwidth consuming programs. Though I might simply be speaking gibberish and there's no possible correlation

> [{quoted}](name=TeCoolMage,realm=OCE,application-id=Ntey9fRZ,discussion-id=5qX1EctO,comment-id=000900000000,timestamp=2015-09-03T11:52:09.323+0000)

It's also a lot harder to fake ping as you'd have to guess around and run several bandwidth consuming programs. Though I might simply be speaking gibberish and there's no possible correlation

The main issue is unfortunately pretty fundamental as all this data is dependent on information coming from the client's PC - it's possible to use software or hardware to intentionally delay your network traffic.

Like I said before, I'm not a complete expert in this field, but just wanted to give insight into why it's a very difficult problem to identify between these cases.

What's your opinion on Quinn and Valor as a coupling of champions?

From a personal stand point, I always like the champions that take a different approach to what a champion is, so I have a soft spot for them. 

The only part I find weird when playing her -  is going from having limited control over Valor via the Harrier passive into full-on control of Valor with no control at all of Quinn. For some reason this bothers me! 

I also generally really like blinds on champions - where the right timing and targetting of the CC actually makes a really big difference about how effective it is. I also like how much of a different kind of role she plays - a very conditionally mobile, assassin style marksman which doesn't really exist anywhere else in League.

Ahoy there!

> Run us through an average day in your shoes at the Riot office.

Typically, I'm usually working on a variety of different kinds of projects - so my typical day tends to vary a lot! 'cause of this, I'll try to go over the kinds of projects that I've been working on!

The core of my job involves data analysis around live issues that negatively impact players. This can involve writing queries that will get the right information back to the right Rioter - or resolving the issue directly. 

The other big part of that involves creating tools that let Riot identify when player-impacting issues are occurring and more detail about what exactly they are. 

I've also worked on Ocean Week earlier this year as well as some of our Player Behaviour projects. 

> have you had any interesting past employments, and what's your second favourite? ;)

I once worked for the Australia Bureau of Statistics and got to play my small part in working on the Census. Interestingly enough, my job wasn't actually related to working on data analytics or gathering at the time... but it was a really fun place to work. You'd be surprised!

There were a lot of really smart people working there who understood their craft to an insane degree. I was already interested in analysing and understanding data -  but it was really cool working at a place that really got the value of data -  as well as all the nitty gritty of how to get it!

> describe the best sandwich you've ever made ( not specifically eaten )

Hrmmmm... When it comes to sandwiches, I'm a complete sucker for toasties. I think the best one I've made involved rare roast beef, blue cheese and a small amount of mustard. So gooooooood.

From a quick look at your traceroutes, it looks like your traffic might be going between two different routes while still within the Telstra network or alternatively there's an issue between two machines within your local internal network before reaching Telstra (depending on if 172.18.* is being used in your local network or not).

Depends on the purpose! The focus of my work is on Live Data - basically data around your connectivity and how you get to play the game.

An example of this is that I do analysis on how well your connection has performed during individual games aggregated across the wider player base to identify problems that are occurring in a particular location or on a particular ISP.  The general focus is on improving the player experience whilst playing league.

When you say player pain, do you mean "omg my connecion/intornet is so stuped" or "QQ"? (Frustration with connectivity vs actual emotional pain)

Do you think Oceania is in good condition compared to other servers in both your field and in general?

It can be both! Player pain is a bit of an abstract concept, that really boils down to "anything that make the player experience crappier". These things can be relatively minor annoyances - all the way up until not being able to play the game. 

Quite a bit of what I do involves identifying and quantifying the impact these things are actually causing people, and then finding the best way to prioritise and resolve those issues with the resources available.

----

I feel like Oceania is pretty well aligned with the worldwide experience of League of Legends. More tailored towards my own field - it's clear that there are some issues with home network connectivity in Australia and the quality of connections that ISPs are able to provide.  

Unfortunately, the ability to improve this part of the connectivity problem directly is outside of our control, but we're always trying to find ways to improve connectivity or bypass issues that can occur - and we've been able to do this in a number of ways since starting up the Oceanic server. 

That said, we're never going to be satisfied with the current state - there's always things we can do to make things better!
